document.docTitle: Kamimuria obtusa Sivec & Stark 2008, sp. n.
document.masterDocTitle: New Species Of Kamimuria Klapálek (Plecoptera: Perlidae) From Thailand And Vietnam, With Notes On Chinese Species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New Species Of Kamimuria Klapálek (Plecoptera: Perlidae) From Thailand And Vietnam, With Notes On Chinese Species

caption.paragraph:
Figs. 33-38.
Kamimuria obtusa
adult structures. 33. Head and pronotum, 34. Male terminalia, 35. Male hemitergal lobe, lateral, 36. Female terminalia, 37. Aedeagus, lateral, 38. Femur.

subSubSection.paragraph: Male. Forewing length 22 mm . Hemitergal lobes short, wide, rounded apically and bearing a small basal callus armed with sensilla basiconica ( Figs. 34- 35 ); a short carina extends along dorsal edge of hemiterga. Tergum 9 with a median patch of sensilla basiconica but sensilla basiconica absent from tergum 8. Aedeagus membranous, cylindrical but strongly narrowed at apex. Armature consists of small to moderate size spines in ventral patch in apical half of sac; patch strongly narrowed on dorsum to an apical or subapical band ( Fig. 37 ).

caption.paragraph:
Figs. 39-42.
Kamimuria obtusa
nymphal structures. 39. Head and pronotum, 40. Abdominal terga 8-10, 41. Foreleg, 42. Maxilla.

subSubSection.paragraph: Female. Forewing length 29 mm . Subgenital plate broadly triangular with an apical emargination or small truncate apex ( Fig. 36 ).

Egg. Outline almost spherical to slightly oval with short, narrow collar; rim of collar scalloped with irregular lumpy projections. Chorion finely punctate throughout; punctations vary slightly in diameter over most of surface but smaller ones occur generally below micropylar line. In equatorial third of egg punctations outline follicle cell impressions with ca. 3-4 pits per cell side; cells enclose simple floors with highly variable numbers of pits, usually clustered near cell centers ( Figs. 78-79 ).
Etymology. The species name refers to the broadly rounded hemitergal tips.

Diagnosis.
Kamimuria obtusa
shares the short, broad hemitergal lobes and aedeagal armature pattern with
K. klapaleki
but can be distinguished by careful comparison of details in aedeagal armature. In
K. obtusa
the armature extends essentially to the aedeagal apex and the patch is continuous on the dorsum forward of the subapical bare spot ( Fig. 37 ), whereas in
K. klapaleki
the apical armature ends well before the tip and the dorsoapical patch is not continuous forward of the subapical bare spot ( Fig. 97 ). Chorionic features including the mesal field of obscure follicle cell impressions composed of rows of pits ( Fig. 78 ) permit recognition of gravid females and larvae were associated through dissection of the aedeagus and eggs from pharate specimens. Although few larvae are known in this genus, and color pattern may not ultimately prove to be a reliable method for species recognition, this species is distinct in head color pattern from
K. tibialis ( Sivec et al. 1988 )
.
